question1a.value:
Null: Pairing students with a mentor will not affect the member retention rate in extracurricular activities.
Alternate: Pairing students with a mentor will increase the member retention rate in extracurricular activities.

question2a.value: Alternate: Participants assigned to the peer mentor will feel more satisfied and confident in their work, in spite of the possibility of making mistakes.

question3a.value: Measuring the satisfaction of the participants will help indicate whether a student having a peer mentor will affect their success in an afterschool activity. For the alternate hypothesis, students with active mentorship will have better rates of satisfaction in their activity and will have the confidence to resume those activities.

question2c.value: Graphing interval data on a linear regression graph.

question3c.value: Mentors will interact with one group of participants and not the others.

q1.value: The effect of drought duration on C mineralization and persistence.

q2.value: Sarah Fansler, Ben Bond-Lamberty, Kaizad Patel

q3.value: This experiment aims to examine the effect of drought duration on soil gas fluxes, pore water concentrations, FTICR, NMR, microbial community composition, and total physical C. This is important because of the uncertainties surrounding how drought and soil moisture could destabilize soil carbon under a changing climate.

q4.value:
H1: Chemical changes due to drying are relatively static, in that once soils have dried to constant weight, the chemical profile of the different pore water domains won’t change for the instant rewet. 
H2: Soils that are dryer longer will have had time for the microbial community to adapt, shift, or acclimate to the drought condition, and will therefore show greater differentiation in their responses to slow rewetting.
H2a: Soils that are dryer longer will experience winnowing of the revivable microbial population, and thus the longer-dried soils (especially 1000 days) will show less differentiation.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a randomized lab experiment in which we randomly assign soil cores to different drought durations and drying types, and then measure them across that time period.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value: Some respiration data have already been collected as this preregistration is written, but those data files have remain unprocessed or viewed, and in fact have been isolated (withheld) from Drs. Bailey and Bond-Lamberty.

question.value: Eighty-six soil cores were collected at Caribou-Poker Creek Research Watershed area northeast of Fairbanks, AK, in September 2018, with full permission from the LTER site manager Jamie Hollingsworth. Six cores were damaged in transit or otherwise judged (a priori, before any measurements) problematic and removed from the experiment. Cores were randomly assigned to treatments. In April 2019, an additional set of cores was collected from Secret River, WA.

q13.value: The total number of samples is 80: 5 time lengths (4, 30, 100, 360, and 1000 days) x 2 wetting directions x 2 drying types x N=4. So there are 80 cores for each site.

q14.value: This was the maximum number of soil cores that could be collected over two days of sampling in the Caribou-Poker Creek Research Watershed area. In addition, previous work (Bond-Lamberty et al. 2016, http://dx.doi.org/10.5194/bg-13-6669-2016) suggests that this is an adequate sample size, allowing for sufficient replicates of each treatment.

q15.value: N/A, although the longest (1000 day) incubation is a priori planned as a separate analysis and publication.

question.value: We are manipulating drought length (30-1000 days) and drying type (dry to constant weight, versus forced drying, beyond that water tension).

Measured variables include cores weights (used to calculate soil moisture, see above); CO2 and CH4 production; soil wettability; pore water chemical composition; water-extractable carbon; and microbial community composition (16S). All of these will be measured after the end of incubations, except the greenhouse gas fluxes, which will be measured throughout both during the drought and upon rewetting.

We will test for differences in our controlled variables (incubation length, wetting direction, etc) via standard ANOVA (R’s car::Anova() procedure) based on a linear, mixed-effects model relating the variable of interest to
Incubation length (categorical)
Wetting direction (categorical)
Drying type (categorical)
Soil moisture status (numeric)
The two-way interactions of these primary effects

To control for the repeated-measures nature of the experiment, particularly with respect to the flux data, the model will include a random effect:
Core (categorical)

q20.value: For greenhouse gas fluxes, the dependent variables (CO2 and/or CH4 flux) may be transformed for statistical normality. We will use the least-skewing transformation possible, e.g. trying logarithmic transformations before square root. This is a standard and accepted step. No other transformations will be used. If we detect gross violations of statistical test assumptions, we will fall back to nonparametric tests (e.g. Mann-Whitney in place of t-test for group mean differences).

q21.value: We will standard statistical thresholds (e.g. alpha=0.05, beta=0.1) and R defaults. Any multiple-condition testing will be controlled via Bonferroni or similar 'protected' tests. In reporting results, we will not treat p-values as hard cutoffs, following the recommendations of the American Statistical Association (Wasserstein et al. 2016, http://dx.doi.org/10.1080/00031305.2016.1154108).

q22.value:
We will exclude two categories of data:
1. Data that are a priori known, or strongly suspected, to be problematic. For example, if an instrument miscalibration is discovered, then we'll exclude all data collected during that period.
2. All models will be tested for influential outliers. If any are present (from R's standard 'lm' diagnostics) we will re-fit the model without them and report both results.

q23.value: Incomplete or missing data will in general be dropped from analyses; there will be no attempt to infer or gap-fill values.

q24.value: We will probably conduct post hoc exploratory analyses based on the findings of our preregistered analyses. All results from these analyses will be clearly differentiated, both in code and publications, from the pre-planned analyses.

attributes.title: Food and Diversity - Adult
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

question2a.value:
a.	Food type (western, conventional, foreign, unconventional, vs. nonfood) is a within-subject variable
b.	Label (label vs. not labeled) is a between-subject variable
c.	Demographic variables are between-subject variables that are self-reported. 
i.	Demographic information:
1.	age in years
2.	gender (male, female, other)
3.	race or ethnicity (7 distinct racial categories and 8th category for bi- or multi-racial)
4.	highest level of education (1= 8th grade of less to 7 = graduate or professional degree)
ii.	Language exposure variables 
1.	Native language (3 categories: English, English-Other language, and Other language)
2.	Regularly hears another language (yes vs. no)
3.	We will group participants into the following categories based on the above two questions: (1) bilingual: has more than one native language; (2) exposure: has only one native language but regularly hears other languages; (3) no exposure: has only one native language and does not regularly hear other languages. 
iii.	Intergroup contact
1.	Quantity of contact with different language speakers (1 = not at all to 5 = a great deal)
2.	Pleasantness of contact with different language speakers (1 = not at all to 5 = a great deal)
3.	Quantity of contact with different race (1 = not at all to 5 = a great deal)
4.	Pleasantness of contact with different race (1 = not at all to 5 = a great deal)
5.	Sum the self-report ratings of the contact quantity with racial and linguistic outgroups to create a “contact quantity” composite score (range 2 to 10)
6.	Sum the self-report ratings of the contact quality with racial and linguistic outgroups to create a “contact quality” composite score (range 2 to 10)
iv.	Political ideology: (1= very conservative to 5= very liberal) from the Gallup (https://news.gallup.com/poll/225074/conservative-lead-ideology-down-single-digits.aspx). 
v.	Neighborhood trust (5 to 25; greater number, greater trust) sum of responses from “social cohesion and trust” scale from Sampson, Raudenbush, and Earls (1997). 
vi.	Neighborhood demographics according to zip code
1.	Zip code
2.	Linguistic diversity in zip code: 2 measures
a.	% of linguistic outgroup speakers (0 to 100%) which is calculated by subtracting the proportion of participant’s language speakers reported in the latest American Community Survey (ACS) from 100%
i.	e.g., for a monolingual English speaker, this will the % of non-English speakers; for a bilingual Spanish-English speaker, this will be the % of non-English & Spanish speakers subtracted from 100% 
b.	Entropy of linguistic diversity (0 to greater; greater positive number, more different language groups accounting for proportion) that uses the number of and proportion of language groups from ACS and is calculated using the R package “entropy” (Hausser & Strimme, 2009)
3.	Racial diversity in zip code: 2 measures
a.	% of racial outgroup population (0 to 100%) which is calculated by subtracting the proportion of participant’s race population reported in ACS from 100%.
i.	e.g., for a Black participant, this will be the % of non-Black population calculated by subtracting the proportion of Black population reported in ACS from 100%
b.	Entropy of racial diversity (0 to greater; greater positive number, more different race groups accounting for proportion) that is calculated the same way as entropy of linguistic diversity but uses ACS on race instead.
4.	Sum the proportion of racial and linguistic outgroup population to create a “outgroup population” composite score (0% to 200%) 
5.	Sum the entropy of racial and linguistic outgroup population to create a “outgroup population entropy” composite score 
6.	Median income in zip code (continuous) that is extracted directly from ACS 
7.	Population density in zip code (number of people per square mile) that is extracted directly from the latest US census
8.	Education level in zip code (the proportion of people with high school diploma or above) extracted directly from ACS.
9.	Access to different cuisines: Using Yelp academic dataset (https://www.yelp.com/dataset/documentation/main), we will calculate the entropy of different cuisines (i.e., assess variety and proportion of different cuisines in zip code) and how many restaurants are in the zip code. We will sum these two metrics to create a “cuisine diversity” score. However, this dataset is only a subset and does not include information on all US zip codes. Therefore, we will use this metric only if we have more than 50 participants who are within this subset Yelp dataset zip code.

question2b.value: a.	Acceptability rating: Rating of how acceptable a food item is to eat (1 = really not okay to 5 = really okay to eat)

question3b.value:
a.	Food neophobia 
1.	Food Neophobia scale (score of 10 to 70, higher meaning more neophobic)
2.	Food Neophobia scale reduced (score of 10 to 49, higher meaning more neophobic): This subscale of the food neophobia scale will not include items 4, 5, and 10, which ask specifically about ethnic foods 

b.	Dietary restrictions
i.	dietary restrictions (yes/ no)
ii.	We will compare whether individuals who respond as having dietary restrictions show different patterns than those who do.

question10b.value:
Participants
	500 adults above the age of 18, located in the U.S., have an approval rating of 75% or above were recruited from Amazon MTurk. Must have correctly answered CAPTCHA (bot detection). 

Design & materials
Participants were randomly assigned to either the label or no label condition. Participants viewed eight items each of western food, conventional combinations, foreign food, unconventional combinations, and nonfood items presented via Qualtrics survey platform. All items had an accompanying picture, one sentence description, and a 5-point scale to indicate how okay it is to eat this item (see Figure 3 for the scale; see supplementary attachment for Qualtrics surveys). For foreign food items, their native language labels were used and for unconventional food items, novel labels were generated by taking novel words from the novel noun database (Horst & Hout, in press) and reversing the letter orders to create non-English sounding labels. See Tables 1 and 2 for the labels and descriptions. Participants completed a demographic survey after the acceptability ratings. 
Demographic information. Participants provided their age, gender, race/ethnicity, native language, regular exposure to non-English language, dietary restrictions, current zip code and highest level of education. 
Familiarity. Participants rated how familiar they were with the foreign foods, unconventional combinations, western foods, and conventional combinations on a 5-point scale (1 = not at all to 5 = a great deal). 
Food neophobia. Participants completed the Food Neophobia Scale (Pliner & Hobden, 1992).
Intergroup contact. Participants completed four questions on quantity and quality of contact they have with people who speak different languages and people who are of a different race from the General Intergroup Contact Quantity and Contact Quality (Islam & Hewstone, 1993).  
Neighborhood trust. Participants completed the social cohesion and trust scale from Sampson, Raudenbush, and Earls (1997). 

Procedure
	Adults accessed the Qualtrics survey via Amazon Mturk and received $1 for completing the survey.

question4b.value:
a.	age 18 and above
b.	located in the U.S.
c.	Have an approval rating of 75% or greater from Amazon Turk
d.	Correctly answer CAPTCHA (bot detection)

question5b.value: a.	from Amazon Mturk using a Qualtrics survey link

question6b.value:
Interaction of food type x label condition (calculated using gpower)

Sample size = 170

Three way interaction of label condition x outgroup population (composite score) x neighborhood trust on foreign food acceptability ratings (calculated using pwr package in r)

pwr.f2.test(u = 12, f2 = (0.3933-0.3584)/(1-(0.3933-0.3584)), sig.level = 0.05, power = 0.8)
predicted sample size needed = v+u+1 = 477+12+1 = 490. Thus, power analysis indicated 490 but considering potential exclusions, we will aim to collect 500.

question7b.value: a.	Once the planned sample size is reached, data collection will be stopped.

question8b.value:
a.	If participants respond with the same response for all items (e.g., participant only chose “okay” for all items) that participant will not be included in the final sample 
b.	For each participant, we will exclude any foreign or unconventional foods items that participants rate as much familiar (score of 4) or higher from analyses. We will exclude any western or conventional food items that participants rate as little familiar (score of 2) or lower from analyses. 
c.	If the response took too short of a time (i.e., less than 1 minute to complete the survey) that participant will be excluded

question1a.value:
1.	Label x Food type interaction: We predict that participants will rate foreign foods and unconventional foods that are labeled as more okay to eat than those that are not labeled. We predict that there will be no label effects on western and conventional foods and non-food items. 
2.	Related factors to acceptability of foreign and unconventional foods
a.	Food neophobia: Participants with greater food neophobia will be more likely to show less acceptance of foreign and unconventional foods
b.	Political ideology: Participants who are more liberal will be more likely to show more acceptance of foreign and unconventional foods
c.	Population density: Greater the population density in the neighborhood, greater the acceptance of foreign and unconventional foods
d.	Access to different cuisines: Greater access to different cuisines, greater acceptance of foreign and unconventional foods
3.	Diversity effect
o	Exposure to outgroup x label: We predict that the more exposure to linguistic and racial outgroup population, the more acceptable participants find foreign and unconventional foods. We expect this effect will be greater in the label condition than the no label condition. In fact, when foods are not labeled, more exposure to outgroup may lead to less acceptance of foreign foods. 
o	Exposure to outgroups x neighborhood trust x label: We predict that the exposure to outgroup population and the level of neighborhood trust will be predictive of acceptability ratings toward foreign foods, but this relation will be dependent on whether participants viewed foreign foods with labels or not. Specifically, if participants live in a neighborhood with high outgroup exposure, the level of neighborhood trust will not impact their acceptability ratings of both the labeled and unlabeled foreign foods. However, if participants live in a neighborhood with low outgroup exposure, the level of neighborhood trust will impact their acceptability ratings: greater neighborhood trust may result in increased acceptability when foreign foods are labeled, but greater neighborhood trust may result in less acceptability when foreign foods are not labeled. 
	Exposure to outgroups will be measured in two ways: (1) by using zipcode based census data and (2) by using self-report measures. We will test whether neighborhood zip code based outgroup exposure is more predictive than self-report measures of outgroup contact quantity and quality.
a.	We will examine whether exposure to linguistic outgroup (i.e., people who speak a different language) or racial outgroup (i.e., people who are of a different race) are more predictive of acceptability. We will also test whether it is just simple exposure to outgroups (i.e., anyone who is different) or variety of exposure to different types of outgroups matter more.
b.	We will also explore whether PCA shows similar separation of exposure to outgroup population versus neighborhood trust/contact quality and test whether PCA components are more predictive than our composite measures of exposure to outgroup.

question2a.value: See descriptions above for interaction directionality.

question3a.value: a.	Familiarity manipulation check: We predict that participants will rate western and conventional foods as more familiar (familiarity rating ranging from 1 = not at all to 5 = a great deal) than foreign and unconventional foods.

question1c.value:
1.	Familiarity manipulation check 
•	Familiarity with food items (1 = not at all to 5 = a great deal) for each item will be averaged across participants.

question2c.value: We will conduct paired samples t-tests comparing whether western foods are rated as more familiar than foreign food and whether conventional foods are rated as more familiar than unconventional food.

question3c.value: IV = food type; DV = familiarity ratings

question1c.value:
4.	Diversity effect
a.	Exposure to outgroup x label
b.	Exposure to outgroups x neighborhood trust x label
•	Outgroup population in neighborhood (census method): The exposure to outgroup population will be the outgroup population composite score and outgroup entropy (see method section for details on how these are calculated).

question2c.value:
•	We will create a linear model with the following predictors: outgroup population composite score, Condition (label vs. no label), population density, median income, education levels, neighborhood trust, outgroup population x neighborhood trust, Condition x outgroup population, Condition x neighborhood trust, Condition x outgroup population x neighborhood trust, and any significant covariates from previous analyses. These predictors will be tested on each food category (foreign, unconventional, western, conventional, and nonfoods). 
•	We will test whether outgroup population entropy composite score substituted instead of outgroup population composite score significantly explains variance in acceptability ratings. We will also compare whether the proportion or entropy method explains more variance. Model fit will be compared using likelihood ratio tests. 
•	We will test whether racial population/entropy and linguistic population/entropy independently explains variance in acceptability ratings. Model fit will be compared using likelihood ratio tests.

question3c.value: IV: outgroup population composite score, Condition (label vs. no label), population density, median income, education levels, neighborhood trust, outgroup population x neighborhood trust, Condition x outgroup population, Condition x neighborhood trust, Condition x outgroup population x neighborhood trust

question4c.value: any significant covariates identified from previous analyses.

question1c.value: •	Contact quantity & quality (self-report method):  This will be the contact quantity composite score and contact quality composite score (see Method section for details on how these are calculated)

question2c.value:
•	We will create a linear model with the following predictors: contact quantity, contact quality, Condition (label vs. no label), population density, median income, education levels, contact quantity x contact quality, Condition x contact quantity, Condition x contact quality, Condition x contact quantity x contact quality, and any significant covariates from previous analyses. These predictors will be tested on each food category (foreign, unconventional, western, conventional, and nonfoods). 
•	We will test whether racial contact and linguistic contact independently explains variance in acceptability ratings. Model fit will be compared using likelihood ratio tests. 
•	We will test whether self-report method or census method explains more variance. Model fit will be compared using likelihood ratio tests.

question3c.value: contact quantity, contact quality, Condition (label vs. no label), population density, median income, education levels, contact quantity x contact quality, Condition x contact quantity, Condition x contact quality, Condition x contact quantity x contact quality

question4c.value: any significant covariates identified from previous analyses.

question1c.value: •	For each participant, we will exclude acceptability ratings of a foreign or unconventional food item that has a familiarity rating of much familiar or higher (i.e., score of 4 or higher). Reversely, if any western or conventional food items are rated as little familiar or lower (score of 2 or lower) those items will be excluded. Then, we will conduct the analyses specified below with these cleaned ratings.

question2c.value:
2.	Label x food type interaction effect:. 
•	We will conduct a mixed ANOVA with food type (western, conventional, foreign, unconventional, and nonfood; within-subject variable) and label type (label vs. non-label; between-subject variable) as predictors and acceptability ratings as the dv. If Mauchly’s test of sphericity are violated, we will use Greenhouse-Geisser corrections. Significant interactions will be further investigated using Holm-corrected post-hoc tests. 
•	If foreign vs. unconventional foods are significantly different, we will conduct the subsequent analyses separately for the two food types. If they are not significantly different, then we will combine across the two food types in the subsequent analyses. In the subsequent analyses therefore we will refer to unconventional and foreign food ratings as “unfamiliar food ratings.”

question3c.value: IV = food type and label type; DV = acceptability ratings

question4c.value:
3.	Food neophobia, dietary restriction, political ideology, and access to different ethnic cuisines as covariates
•	We will conduct a Pearson correlation (if normality is violated we will use Kendall's tau-b) between foreign and unconventional food acceptability ratings and food neophobia ratings.
•	We will also conduct a Pearson correlation (if normality is violated we will use Kendall's tau-b) between acceptability ratings of foreign and unconventional food and political ideology ratings.
•	We will conduct a point biserial correlation between dietary restriction (yes/no) and acceptability ratings of foreign and unconventional food
•	We will conduct a Pearson correlation (if normality is violated we will use Kendall's tau-b) between acceptability ratings of foreign and unconventional food and access to different ethnic cuisines (but only if we have at least 50 participants with this metric)
•	If these correlations are significant, we will enter them as covariates into the ANOVA models specified above and in the subsequent analyses. If correlations are not significant, they will not be included.

question1c.value: All demographic variables collected (see method section for details).

question2c.value:
•	PCA:
•	We will conduct a PCA with all the collected demographic variables to determine if we replicate the PCA we found in Study 1. We predict that there will be following components: 1) PC1 = quantity of diversity (both language and race outgroup population in zip code and self-reports of language and race contact quantity); 2) PC2 = quality of interactions with different others (self-reports of language and race contact quality and neighborhood trust); 3) PC3 = education and age; 4) PC4 = dietary restrictions; 5) PC5 = political ideology 
•	We will test the three-way and two-way interaction effects of the Condition (label vs no label), PC1 (quantity of diversity) component, and PC2 (quality of interactions with different other) component using the same linear model used for the composite scores in the previous analyses to determine whether PCA components also significantly explains variance in acceptability ratings.

registration_responses.datacompletion: No, data collection has not begun
registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question1a:
1.	Label x Food type interaction: We predict that participants will rate foreign foods and unconventional foods that are labeled as more okay to eat than those that are not labeled. We predict that there will be no label effects on western and conventional foods and non-food items. 
2.	Related factors to acceptability of foreign and unconventional foods
a.	Food neophobia: Participants with greater food neophobia will be more likely to show less acceptance of foreign and unconventional foods
b.	Political ideology: Participants who are more liberal will be more likely to show more acceptance of foreign and unconventional foods
c.	Population density: Greater the population density in the neighborhood, greater the acceptance of foreign and unconventional foods
d.	Access to different cuisines: Greater access to different cuisines, greater acceptance of foreign and unconventional foods
3.	Diversity effect
o	Exposure to outgroup x label: We predict that the more exposure to linguistic and racial outgroup population, the more acceptable participants find foreign and unconventional foods. We expect this effect will be greater in the label condition than the no label condition. In fact, when foods are not labeled, more exposure to outgroup may lead to less acceptance of foreign foods. 
o	Exposure to outgroups x neighborhood trust x label: We predict that the exposure to outgroup population and the level of neighborhood trust will be predictive of acceptability ratings toward foreign foods, but this relation will be dependent on whether participants viewed foreign foods with labels or not. Specifically, if participants live in a neighborhood with high outgroup exposure, the level of neighborhood trust will not impact their acceptability ratings of both the labeled and unlabeled foreign foods. However, if participants live in a neighborhood with low outgroup exposure, the level of neighborhood trust will impact their acceptability ratings: greater neighborhood trust may result in increased acceptability when foreign foods are labeled, but greater neighborhood trust may result in less acceptability when foreign foods are not labeled. 
	Exposure to outgroups will be measured in two ways: (1) by using zipcode based census data and (2) by using self-report measures. We will test whether neighborhood zip code based outgroup exposure is more predictive than self-report measures of outgroup contact quantity and quality.
a.	We will examine whether exposure to linguistic outgroup (i.e., people who speak a different language) or racial outgroup (i.e., people who are of a different race) are more predictive of acceptability. We will also test whether it is just simple exposure to outgroups (i.e., anyone who is different) or variety of exposure to different types of outgroups matter more.
b.	We will also explore whether PCA shows similar separation of exposure to outgroup population versus neighborhood trust/contact quality and test whether PCA components are more predictive than our composite measures of exposure to outgroup.
registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question2a: See descriptions above for interaction directionality.
registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question3a: a.	Familiarity manipulation check: We predict that participants will rate western and conventional foods as more familiar (familiarity rating ranging from 1 = not at all to 5 = a great deal) than foreign and unconventional foods.
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2a:
a.	Food type (western, conventional, foreign, unconventional, vs. nonfood) is a within-subject variable
b.	Label (label vs. not labeled) is a between-subject variable
c.	Demographic variables are between-subject variables that are self-reported. 
i.	Demographic information:
1.	age in years
2.	gender (male, female, other)
3.	race or ethnicity (7 distinct racial categories and 8th category for bi- or multi-racial)
4.	highest level of education (1= 8th grade of less to 7 = graduate or professional degree)
ii.	Language exposure variables 
1.	Native language (3 categories: English, English-Other language, and Other language)
2.	Regularly hears another language (yes vs. no)
3.	We will group participants into the following categories based on the above two questions: (1) bilingual: has more than one native language; (2) exposure: has only one native language but regularly hears other languages; (3) no exposure: has only one native language and does not regularly hear other languages. 
iii.	Intergroup contact
1.	Quantity of contact with different language speakers (1 = not at all to 5 = a great deal)
2.	Pleasantness of contact with different language speakers (1 = not at all to 5 = a great deal)
3.	Quantity of contact with different race (1 = not at all to 5 = a great deal)
4.	Pleasantness of contact with different race (1 = not at all to 5 = a great deal)
5.	Sum the self-report ratings of the contact quantity with racial and linguistic outgroups to create a “contact quantity” composite score (range 2 to 10)
6.	Sum the self-report ratings of the contact quality with racial and linguistic outgroups to create a “contact quality” composite score (range 2 to 10)
iv.	Political ideology: (1= very conservative to 5= very liberal) from the Gallup (https://news.gallup.com/poll/225074/conservative-lead-ideology-down-single-digits.aspx). 
v.	Neighborhood trust (5 to 25; greater number, greater trust) sum of responses from “social cohesion and trust” scale from Sampson, Raudenbush, and Earls (1997). 
vi.	Neighborhood demographics according to zip code
1.	Zip code
2.	Linguistic diversity in zip code: 2 measures
a.	% of linguistic outgroup speakers (0 to 100%) which is calculated by subtracting the proportion of participant’s language speakers reported in the latest American Community Survey (ACS) from 100%
i.	e.g., for a monolingual English speaker, this will the % of non-English speakers; for a bilingual Spanish-English speaker, this will be the % of non-English & Spanish speakers subtracted from 100% 
b.	Entropy of linguistic diversity (0 to greater; greater positive number, more different language groups accounting for proportion) that uses the number of and proportion of language groups from ACS and is calculated using the R package “entropy” (Hausser & Strimme, 2009)
3.	Racial diversity in zip code: 2 measures
a.	% of racial outgroup population (0 to 100%) which is calculated by subtracting the proportion of participant’s race population reported in ACS from 100%.
i.	e.g., for a Black participant, this will be the % of non-Black population calculated by subtracting the proportion of Black population reported in ACS from 100%
b.	Entropy of racial diversity (0 to greater; greater positive number, more different race groups accounting for proportion) that is calculated the same way as entropy of linguistic diversity but uses ACS on race instead.
4.	Sum the proportion of racial and linguistic outgroup population to create a “outgroup population” composite score (0% to 200%) 
5.	Sum the entropy of racial and linguistic outgroup population to create a “outgroup population entropy” composite score 
6.	Median income in zip code (continuous) that is extracted directly from ACS 
7.	Population density in zip code (number of people per square mile) that is extracted directly from the latest US census
8.	Education level in zip code (the proportion of people with high school diploma or above) extracted directly from ACS.
9.	Access to different cuisines: Using Yelp academic dataset (https://www.yelp.com/dataset/documentation/main), we will calculate the entropy of different cuisines (i.e., assess variety and proportion of different cuisines in zip code) and how many restaurants are in the zip code. We will sum these two metrics to create a “cuisine diversity” score. However, this dataset is only a subset and does not include information on all US zip codes. Therefore, we will use this metric only if we have more than 50 participants who are within this subset Yelp dataset zip code.
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2b: a.	Acceptability rating: Rating of how acceptable a food item is to eat (1 = really not okay to 5 = really okay to eat)
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question3b:
a.	Food neophobia 
1.	Food Neophobia scale (score of 10 to 70, higher meaning more neophobic)
2.	Food Neophobia scale reduced (score of 10 to 49, higher meaning more neophobic): This subscale of the food neophobia scale will not include items 4, 5, and 10, which ask specifically about ethnic foods 

b.	Dietary restrictions
i.	dietary restrictions (yes/ no)
ii.	We will compare whether individuals who respond as having dietary restrictions show different patterns than those who do.
registration_responses.description-methods.procedure.question10:
Participants
	500 adults above the age of 18, located in the U.S., have an approval rating of 75% or above were recruited from Amazon MTurk. Must have correctly answered CAPTCHA (bot detection). 

Design & materials
Participants were randomly assigned to either the label or no label condition. Participants viewed eight items each of western food, conventional combinations, foreign food, unconventional combinations, and nonfood items presented via Qualtrics survey platform. All items had an accompanying picture, one sentence description, and a 5-point scale to indicate how okay it is to eat this item (see Figure 3 for the scale; see supplementary attachment for Qualtrics surveys). For foreign food items, their native language labels were used and for unconventional food items, novel labels were generated by taking novel words from the novel noun database (Horst & Hout, in press) and reversing the letter orders to create non-English sounding labels. See Tables 1 and 2 for the labels and descriptions. Participants completed a demographic survey after the acceptability ratings. 
Demographic information. Participants provided their age, gender, race/ethnicity, native language, regular exposure to non-English language, dietary restrictions, current zip code and highest level of education. 
Familiarity. Participants rated how familiar they were with the foreign foods, unconventional combinations, western foods, and conventional combinations on a 5-point scale (1 = not at all to 5 = a great deal). 
Food neophobia. Participants completed the Food Neophobia Scale (Pliner & Hobden, 1992).
Intergroup contact. Participants completed four questions on quantity and quality of contact they have with people who speak different languages and people who are of a different race from the General Intergroup Contact Quantity and Contact Quality (Islam & Hewstone, 1993).  
Neighborhood trust. Participants completed the social cohesion and trust scale from Sampson, Raudenbush, and Earls (1997). 

Procedure
	Adults accessed the Qualtrics survey via Amazon Mturk and received $1 for completing the survey.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-first.first.questi:
1.	Familiarity manipulation check 
•	Familiarity with food items (1 = not at all to 5 = a great deal) for each item will be averaged across participants.
We will conduct paired samples t-tests comparing whether western foods are rated as more familiar than foreign food and whether conventional foods are rated as more familiar than unconventional food.
IV = food type; DV = familiarity ratings
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-third.third.questi:
4.	Diversity effect
a.	Exposure to outgroup x label
b.	Exposure to outgroups x neighborhood trust x label
•	Outgroup population in neighborhood (census method): The exposure to outgroup population will be the outgroup population composite score and outgroup entropy (see method section for details on how these are calculated).

•	We will create a linear model with the following predictors: outgroup population composite score, Condition (label vs. no label), population density, median income, education levels, neighborhood trust, outgroup population x neighborhood trust, Condition x outgroup population, Condition x neighborhood trust, Condition x outgroup population x neighborhood trust, and any significant covariates from previous analyses. These predictors will be tested on each food category (foreign, unconventional, western, conventional, and nonfoods). 
•	We will test whether outgroup population entropy composite score substituted instead of outgroup population composite score significantly explains variance in acceptability ratings. We will also compare whether the proportion or entropy method explains more variance. Model fit will be compared using likelihood ratio tests. 
•	We will test whether racial population/entropy and linguistic population/entropy independently explains variance in acceptability ratings. Model fit will be compared using likelihood ratio tests.

IV: outgroup population composite score, Condition (label vs. no label), population density, median income, education levels, neighborhood trust, outgroup population x neighborhood trust, Condition x outgroup population, Condition x neighborhood trust, Condition x outgroup population x neighborhood trust
any significant covariates identified from previous analyses.
registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest:
a.	age 18 and above
b.	located in the U.S.
c.	Have an approval rating of 75% or greater from Amazon Turk
d.	Correctly answer CAPTCHA (bot detection)
a.	from Amazon Mturk using a Qualtrics survey link

Interaction of food type x label condition (calculated using gpower)

Sample size = 170

Three way interaction of label condition x outgroup population (composite score) x neighborhood trust on foreign food acceptability ratings (calculated using pwr package in r)

pwr.f2.test(u = 12, f2 = (0.3933-0.3584)/(1-(0.3933-0.3584)), sig.level = 0.05, power = 0.8)
predicted sample size needed = v+u+1 = 477+12+1 = 490. Thus, power analysis indicated 490 but considering potential exclusions, we will aim to collect 500.
a.	Once the planned sample size is reached, data collection will be stopped.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-fourth.fourth.ques: •	Contact quantity & quality (self-report method):  This will be the contact quantity composite score and contact quality composite score (see Method section for details on how these are calculated)

•	We will create a linear model with the following predictors: contact quantity, contact quality, Condition (label vs. no label), population density, median income, education levels, contact quantity x contact quality, Condition x contact quantity, Condition x contact quality, Condition x contact quantity x contact quality, and any significant covariates from previous analyses. These predictors will be tested on each food category (foreign, unconventional, western, conventional, and nonfoods). 
•	We will test whether racial contact and linguistic contact independently explains variance in acceptability ratings. Model fit will be compared using likelihood ratio tests. 
•	We will test whether self-report method or census method explains more variance. Model fit will be compared using likelihood ratio tests.

contact quantity, contact quality, Condition (label vs. no label), population density, median income, education levels, contact quantity x contact quality, Condition x contact quantity, Condition x contact quality, Condition x contact quantity x contact quality
any significant covariates identified from previous analyses.

registration_responses.description-methods.exclusion-criteria.q:
a.	If participants respond with the same response for all items (e.g., participant only chose “okay” for all items) that participant will not be included in the final sample 
b.	For each participant, we will exclude any foreign or unconventional foods items that participants rate as much familiar (score of 4) or higher from analyses. We will exclude any western or conventional food items that participants rate as little familiar (score of 2) or lower from analyses. 
c.	If the response took too short of a time (i.e., less than 1 minute to complete the survey) that participant will be excluded

attributes.title: Linking Life Events and Value Orientations: Contributions from Longitudinal Multi-Rater and Twin Data

q1.value: Linking Life Events and Value Orientations: Contributions from Multi-Rater and Twin Data

q3.value: Past research showed that values are stable to the point that even major life events (LEs) do not consistently lead to systematic value changes. This study contributes to the research body by considering the (non-)occurrence, valence, and perceived controllability of events across main life areas in adolescents and adults of all ages. I will use multi-rater and twin data from two data waves (two years apart) of the Study of Personality Architecture and Dynamics (SPeADy). Second-wave data are being currently collected and will be available in Spring 2020. The SPeADy LE questionnaire comprises 19 LE categories that encompass the domains (1) qualification, work, and finances, (2) social life, and (3) health and threatening experiences. Values are measured with the Portrait Values Questionnaire-Revised.

q4.value:
1. The importance of self-enhancement values increases following an important personal qualification (H1.1a) and/or a significant personal success (H1.2a). These relations strengthen with the life event’s rated positivity (H1.1b and H1.2b). The importance of self-enhancement decreases following a significant personal failure (H1.3a). This relation strengthens with the failure’s rated negativity (H1.3b).

2. The importance of personal focus values increases following the start of a new qualification or professional phase (H2.1a), a major interpersonal conflict (H2.2a), and/or a relationship dissolution (H2.3a). These relations strengthen with the life event’s rated valence strength (H2.1b, H2.2b, and H2.3b).

3. The importance of self-protection values increases following one’s own serious illness or injury (H3.1a) and/or one’s own mental illness or addiction problems (H3.2a). These relations strengthen with the life event’s rated negativity (H3.1b and H3.2b).

4. The importance of social focus values increases following a pregnancy, one’s child’s birth or adoption (H4.1a) and/or a serious physical or mental illness, injury or death of close others (H4.2a). The respective relation strengthens with the former life event’s rated positivity (H4.1b) and with the latter life event’s rated negativity (H4.2b).

5. Intraindividual value change rises with the amount of life events (H5a) and with increasing life events’ rated valence strength (H5b).

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value: Longitudinal data on German-speaking adolescents (14 years or older) and adults of all ages will be received from the PI of the Study of Personality Architecture and Dynamics (SPeADy). Data comprise a multi-rater sample (self- and informant reports) and a twin family sample (including mono- and dizygotic twins).

q13.value: Depending on drop-out rates probably 350 to 400 target-informant pairs and 350 to 400 twin pairs.

question.value:
Predictor variables: 19 life events with respective 7-point valence and controllability ratings
Outcome variables: Value orientations based on the 57-item Portrait Value Questionnaire-Revised
Covariates: Age, Sex, HEXACO personality traits based on the 60-item HEXACO-PI-R
Analytical strategies include propensity score analyses and genetically informed regression analyses.

registration_responses.q3: Past research showed that values are stable to the point that even major life events (LEs) do not consistently lead to systematic value changes. This study contributes to the research body by considering the (non-)occurrence, valence, and perceived controllability of events across main life areas in adolescents and adults of all ages. I will use multi-rater and twin data from two data waves (two years apart) of the Study of Personality Architecture and Dynamics (SPeADy). Second-wave data are being currently collected and will be available in Spring 2020. The SPeADy LE questionnaire comprises 19 LE categories that encompass the domains (1) qualification, work, and finances, (2) social life, and (3) health and threatening experiences. Values are measured with the Portrait Values Questionnaire-Revised.
registration_responses.q4:
1. The importance of self-enhancement values increases following an important personal qualification (H1.1a) and/or a significant personal success (H1.2a). These relations strengthen with the life event’s rated positivity (H1.1b and H1.2b). The importance of self-enhancement decreases following a significant personal failure (H1.3a). This relation strengthens with the failure’s rated negativity (H1.3b).

2. The importance of personal focus values increases following the start of a new qualification or professional phase (H2.1a), a major interpersonal conflict (H2.2a), and/or a relationship dissolution (H2.3a). These relations strengthen with the life event’s rated valence strength (H2.1b, H2.2b, and H2.3b).

3. The importance of self-protection values increases following one’s own serious illness or injury (H3.1a) and/or one’s own mental illness or addiction problems (H3.2a). These relations strengthen with the life event’s rated negativity (H3.1b and H3.2b).

4. The importance of social focus values increases following a pregnancy, one’s child’s birth or adoption (H4.1a) and/or a serious physical or mental illness, injury or death of close others (H4.2a). The respective relation strengthens with the former life event’s rated positivity (H4.1b) and with the latter life event’s rated negativity (H4.2b).

5. Intraindividual value change rises with the amount of life events (H5a) and with increasing life events’ rated valence strength (H5b).
